item.title: New Bundle Collects Two Of The Best SpongeBob Switch Games For $35
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

SpongeBob has gone on plenty of video game adventures, and on October 31, you can grab a physical edition of the SpongeBob SquarePants: Bundle that collects two of SpongeBob's best games--Battle for Bikini Bottom Rehydrated and The Cosmic Shake--into a single physical release. Preorders for the two-game collection are available at Amazon for just $35--that's a 50% price cut compared to the digital version of the bundle that's already available for $70 on the Switch eShop.

The Cosmic Shake is the better (and newer) of the two games, and it earned solid marks from critics. Our Cosmic Shake review gave it a 7/10, thanks to its classic SpongeBob humor and enjoyable platforming segments. "Despite a few hiccups and disappointing aspects of The Cosmic Shake design, at its core it achieves its goals," writes GameSpot reviewer James Carr.

The other game in the bundle, Battle for Bikini Bottom Rehydrated, earned similar reviews, giving nostalgic fans a massive version of the underwater town to roam around as SpongeBob, Patrick, and Sandy.

This new Switch physical edition bundle isn't the only way to get your SpongeBob fix. Fans can preorder the next SpongeBob game, Titans of the Tides, which puts you in the middle of a conflict between the Flying Dutchman and King Neptune. It launches for $40 on November 18 for Nintendo Switch 2, PS5, Xbox Series X, and PC. If you're playing on Xbox Series X or PS5, check out the digital Bikini Bottom Bundle that includes The Cosmic Shake, Titans of the Tide, and Battle for Bikini Bottom for $90.

SpongeBob will also appear as a playable character in the upcoming Nicktoons Dice of Destiny family-friendly action-RPG adventure that sees up to three other players team up and hack and slash their way throughout a cross-over world featuring numerous fan-favorite Nicktoons. The game launches on September 30 for Switch, PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC. Physical console edition preorders are available for $50. There's also an $80 Collector's Edition available for $80 on PS5 and Switch that features the base game plus extra in-game content, a set of physical trading cards, a poster, a sticker sheet, and more.

For something different, check out The Patrick Star Game or Krusty Cook-Off. The former sees the lovable starfish getting his very own physics-based adventure, while the latter has you cooking up delicious meals to serve hungry customers. It's radically different from the 3D platformers in the upcoming SpongeBob SquarePants: Bundle, so give it a look if you want something unique to help bide your time.

item.title: A Decade Ago, The Taken King Saved Destiny--And Then Cursed It
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Destiny: The Taken King is celebrating its 10-year anniversary today, September 15, 2025. Below, we look back at how it came to represent the years of Destiny, and live-service games more broadly, that would follow.

Ten years ago, Bungie performed a miracle. It also, unfortunately, invoked a curse.

In 2014, the studio renowned for the Halo franchise launched Destiny, which promised to blend its penchant for dynamic single-player campaigns and kinetic multiplayer gameplay with the framework and community-oriented features of MMOs. And while the game was released to an excited and impressionable audience, it floundered. Its opening salvo felt limp and incomplete--a sentiment that later reporting would confirm--but it maintained a playerbase through a spate of smaller middling DLC releases leading up to The Taken King, Destiny's first major expansion and saving grace.

The Taken King launched on September 15, 2015 and--I say this without exaggeration--revolutionized the game, which felt aimless till its arrival. Destiny's worlds, while large and beautiful, felt quiet and devoid of life. Its cast felt more like disparate archetypes thrown in a blender than a cohesive company. And its paper-thin plot...well, it was just that. Destiny wasn't without merit--it excelled in gunplay, boasted an art style that blended sci-fi and fantasy seamlessly, and the level design of its strikes and raids were still exemplary--but all of that felt pointed at nothing in particular. The Taken King whipped it into shape.

From its opening mission through to the riotous end of its raid, The Taken King was sharp in a way the initial release of Destiny could only ever dream of. For 10 years now, I've been struck by the construction of the expansion's first level, where the player must mount a defense of a besieged base on Phobos, and how much livelier it felt than anything Destiny had done in the year prior. Small touches, like an enemy ship cresting over a hill and shining its spotlight on the player, as well as the sights and sounds of explosions in the distance, finally broke up the almost glacial front that permeated Destiny's destinations. It was like throwing a rock into still water.

The Taken King finally provided a worthy and meaningful antagonist in Oryx, whose impact and brood still have ramifications on the world of Destiny to this day. It breathed life into characters that could've fallen by the wayside, like Eris Morn. It provided a bounty of secrets nestled in the crevices of the Dreadnaught. Hell, it even gave players a quest log! It cannot be overstated how amorphous Destiny felt before The Taken King's arrival, and how wonderful it felt to bask in it for the weeks and months to come. It hadn't just come to life, but become even larger in scope. At last, I felt like I was taking part in the epic struggle between light and darkness that Destiny had been billed as while I flitted through the cosmos and used my spectacular powers and weaponry to live out the adventures of my dreams.

For all intents and purposes, Destiny had mounted the comeback it needed. With some narrative direction and goodwill on its side, it had enough gas to continue its ascent. So what curse could I possibly have been referring to earlier?

The unfortunate problem with Destiny is that it never stopped needing saving. If you're at all familiar with the arc of the series, you may be tangentially aware of the bumpy road the games, as well as the company behind it, have been on ever since. For every high--every Taken King or Forsaken, which came at a similar time in Destiny 2's lifetime--there have been some standout lows. Unfortunately, while Destiny's history is marked by a long line of comebacks, it's just as stained by these immense valleys, brought on often by frequent retooling and reinvention that steadily eroded any ground which could provide it stable footing. And even though Destiny had proven, much like Rainbow Six Siege and No Man's Sky, that a live-service game could bounce back, it also stood as proof positive of how volatile ongoing games could be. It has typified the often harsh ebb and flow of the model.

You see, Destiny never really enjoyed a sense of stability. While Bungie devised a way forward for its ambitious series, the games suffered content droughts that turned its community against the game at several points in its lengthy lifetime. To solve this problem, Bungie figured out a cadence and template for content drops, like expansions, title updates, and seasonal events, that would supplement the community and feed the machine.

We often talk about the live-service treadmill from the perspective of the consumer, which is always a helpful viewpoint to contextualize its impact and potential harm. But what often feels under-discussed is the effect that this work has on the people who make the content for these never-ending games. And while some titles, like Epic Games' Fortnite, seemingly have the capital to throw armies at the thing, the same isn't true of every team.

The cadence of releases under the Destiny banner have seemed increasingly exhaustive on the workforce producing it, especially when factoring in the constant expectations for the next additions to the game to be bigger and better. The live-service treadmill isn't the only thing killing Destiny though. Paired with the mismanagement of the studio under previous leadership, a toxic workplace culture, as well as constant layoffs and reinventions--some better than others--it's no surprise that Destiny's lineage is riddled with instability.

Sometimes that cadence of releases meant that game-changing updates like The Taken King would shake things up for the better. But just as often, it meant that the realities of developing such a big expansion for Destiny caught up with the team behind it. Things fell short. Other expansions like Rise of Iron or Beyond Light felt half-baked, even if they were well-intentioned. Seasons, which were introduced in Destiny 2, felt like a bit of triage that allayed many storytelling and content woes but opened up another can of worms entirely over the years due to repetitive tasks and the removal of seasonal content. Some system-level changes, like reworks to classes, were welcome while others, like the introduction of the Portal, were not. The gulf between Destiny releases has often left a lot to be desired and it has meant that for every two steps that Destiny appeared to take, it would constantly take one back.

Where does The Taken King fall into this, exactly? Well, it arguably set the bar pretty high for what Destiny releases should be, and though Bungie has lived up to that promise a few times over the 10-plus years it's worked on the series, these ambitions have made for just as many misses as there have been hits.

It established an unfortunate rhythm of Bungie amending its errors, showing unprecedented strength, and then showing how that hubris could just as easily be the studio's undoing. Like clockwork, Bungie has spent the last decade and change stepping on rakes and bouncing back better than ever only to further upset the balance of things in Destiny and inadvertently step on another five rakes, which only landed there by the studio's own actions.

It's unfair to place the blame for Destiny's unevenness on one its earliest and best expansions. It would be a mischaracterization of the DLC and the intent behind it. The Taken King isn't a stain on Destiny's legacy because it's too good. That's a ridiculous thing to propose. But it certainly did set the game and the team behind it on a trajectory that has, at the very least, proved untenable for the studio and the health of the game in the long term.

So for all the good that Taken King did Destiny by saving it back then, it's hard to deny that it has made for a tough act to follow, and chasing it after its highs has indelibly marked the studio. It is simultaneously emblematic of the best Destiny would offer, and the lows it would constantly have to recover from.

Madden NFL 26 is already on sale for a substantial discount at multiple major retailers. item.title: Battlefield 6 Devs Love The Sniper Memes, But Know They Have Work To Do
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Between now and the launch of Battlefield 6 next month, Battlefield Studios and its developers will be working to refine the game based on what was learned during the recent beta test. Players have already shared their responses to the beta with some bitingly funny memes, including some about the game's sniper flare. The Battlefield 6 team has seen those pics, and they think they're hilarious.

Battlefield 6 technical director Christian Buhl and senior console combat designer Matthew Nickerson recently spoke with IGN about the upcoming release. When asked about the memes, Buhl admitted to laughing at them while also taking their points to heart.

"I saw those ... I thought it was hilarious," said Buhl. "Obviously, we needed to fix some things and tune some things, so it was funny to see players react in a humorous way to those things, but also great to get that feedback and say, 'We need to tune down snipers or we need to change the glints so it's not like…' you know? I saw those memes with the hillside just full of these giant glares."

Nickerson added that the design team shares the memes internally, and he praised the effort made by fans to address the issues of the game through humor.

"They're really, really funny, and they kind of magnify, 'Hey, we still have work to do,'" said Nickerson. "For example, with the sniper glint stuff, we knew it was too strong, so we stepped it back. We knew the bullet tracer effect was too strong, so we stepped it back ... At the end of the day, it keeps us honest. It keeps us, like, 'Hey, we still have work to do. There are things that players are, maybe, not vibing with or are vibing with in different capacities.' ... From a design standpoint and from the team, we love this stuff. The community is engaged; we are engaged."

In the same interview, Nickerson addressed the team's approach to open class weapons and locked weapons, and shared the team's desire to let the players decide. A recently leaked Battlefield 6 skin had some players revolting against the non-traditional design that may be out of place in the game's realistic military aesthetics. Battlefield Studios subsequently confirmed that its skins and cosmetics will remain "gritty" and "grounded."

EA will reveal the details about Battlefield 6's story mode on September 26. The game's battle royale mode was unveiled earlier this month. Battlefield 6 will hit PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC on October 10.

item.title: Super Mario Bros. Wonder For Switch 2 May Add A Fan-Favorite Character
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Super Mario Bros. Wonder is getting a Switch 2 Edition, and now fans think Nintendo may have accidentally revealed Rosalina will become new playable character.

The trailer for the Switch 2 version of Super Mario Bros. Wonder that premiered during the most recent Nintendo Direct focused on the addition of Bellabel Park, a collection of multiplayer minigames exclusive to the Switch 2 version where players can either team up or compete against each other. One eagle-eyed fan, DynamoSuperX on X (via IGN), spotted a vs minigame icon at around the 2:00 minute mark in the trailer that clearly shows an image of Yoshi next to Rosalina, seemingly confirming her inclusion in the upcoming rerelease of the platformer.

Rosalina isn't in the original version of the game. However, Nintendo did state during the trailer that there would be additional new content coming to the Switch 2 Edition of Super Mario Bros. Wonder, but that it would share more details at a later date. It certainly seems like Rosalina might be one of the surprises Nintendo was looking to keep under wraps until closer to the game's release.

Her inclusion would make sense given Nintendo's all-in push for Super Mario Galaxy. Nintendo during its latest direct announced remastered versions of Super Mario Galaxy 1+2 are coming this year and that the name of Universal's Super Mario Bros. Movie sequel, scheduled to release April 2026, will be The Super Mario Galaxy Movie. Rosalina was introduced in the first Super Mario Galaxy back in 2007, and fans can even preorder a physical version of Rosalina's storybook from the game.

Super Mario Bros. Wonder + Meet Up In Bellabel Park is slated to release in 2026, joining a growing collection of Switch games like Super Mario Party Jamboree and Kirby and The Forgotten Land with Switch 2 Editions that pack in exclusive content.

item.title: Delta Force X Saw May Be The Wildest Crossover Collaboration This Year
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

There have been some off-the-wall year collaborations in the past year, including the Beavis and Butt-Head skins in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6. However, developer Team Jade may have the wildest one of the year with the upcoming Delta Force x Saw crossover. In the teaser video, Saw's Jigsaw killer seemingly enters the world of this free-to-play first-person tactical shooter with a life or death ultimatum.

In the Saw films, the original Jigsaw killer, John Kramer, has been dead for almost two decades. And neither he nor his successors wore life-sized costumes based on Billy the Puppet. But the man behind Billy's mask in this clip certainly knows Kramer's modus operandi and his favorite catchphrases. It's only at the end of the video that he reveals himself as operator D-Wolf. This isn't the first time that Saw has crossed over into games, as Billy appeared in Fortnite and Call of Duty.

D-Wolf's Billy the Puppet skin will make its in-game debut on October 23--just in time for Halloween--alongside firearms and other items inspired by the Saw films. In the meantime, a new Delta Force season, War Ablaze, will begin on September 23. On that date, the game will introduce two new modes, Operation Warden and Operation Raven, as well as a new Warfare map called Fault. Additionally, a new operator, Raptor, will be added to the game's roster.

Last month, Delta Force reached a new peak of concurrent players on Steam with 210,000. The game has steadily built up a following since its debut in December 2024. However, it appears that Delta Force is far more popular internationally than it is domestically, since it doesn't regularly show up in Circana's US engagement reports.

As for the Saw movies, a new collection of Saw 4K Steelbook Editions are available for preorder on Amazon. Earlier this summer, Blumhouse picked up a controlling stake in the Saw franchise, which will bring the original director, James Wan, back in a creative role for the first time since Saw 3 in 2006.

item.title: Popular Multiplayer Soccer Game Rematch Getting A Physical Release
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

EA Sports FC 26 might be the most popular soccer (er, football) game on the horizon, but it's not the only one you can look forward to later this year. After launching digitally earlier this year, the 5v5 online multiplayer soccer game Rematch is getting a physical Elite Edition release on November 14 for PS5, Xbox Series X, and PC. Developed by Slocap, the same studio responsible for Sifu and Absolver, Rematch takes a truly unique approach to the sport, and it's proven to be popular with fans seeking a fun alternative to the EA Sports FC series. Preorders for the PS5 physical Rematch Elite Edition are now available for $40 at Amazon; Xbox and PC physical edition preorders should also be available soon. While there are currently no preorder bonuses, it does come loaded with additional in-game content, which we've detailed below.

Rematch Elite Edition

$40 | Releases November 14

The physical Rematch Elite Edition includes a physical copy of the game, plus a bundle of in-game extras. Here's a look at what's included:

  • Base game
  • Captain Pass Upgrade Ticket (x2)
  • Blazon Player Background and Title
  • Blazon Buckler Tank Top
  • Blazon Pattern for Top and Bottom clothes
  • Blazon Jewel Set
  • Glitcher Trainers
  • Blazon Augmented Reality Cage
  • Blazon Cap

As mentioned above, Amazon currently only has preorders available for the PS5 edition, though Xbox and PC physical preorders should be available soon.

Rematch is also available now in multiple digital versions for PS5, Xbox, and PC via Steam, including a $30 standard edition, $40 Rematch Pro Edition, and a digital version of the Elite Edition for $40. That means that the new physical Elite Edition is $10 than the digital version and includes the same content. However, PC players can snag a discount on all three versions if they grab the game through Fanatical. With Fanatical's discounts, the PC standard edition is just $25.79 (was $30), the Pro Edition is $34.39 (was $40), and the Elite Edition is $43 (was $50). Games purchased from Fanatical are delivered as official Steam keys.

Rematch Deals at Fanatical (Steam)

  • Rematch standard edition -- $27.79 ($30)
  • Rematch Pro Edition -- $34.39 ($40)
  • Rematch Elite Edition -- $43 ($50)

Rematch Elite Edition's fast-paced and arcade-style gameplay differs from other soccer video games, such as EA Sports FC. Only five players field the pitch per team, and there are no fouls, offsides, or out of bounds. In fact, each pitch is enclosed in invisible walls that players can bounce the ball off of, making for a totally unique take on the popular sport. Our Rematch review gave Rematch a 7/10, highlighting its unique skill-based gameplay, satisfying shooting mechanics, and the need for teamwork to win a match. "It's a different kind of football game, yet it's intuitive, and the allure of improving your skill level is captivating," wrote critic Richard Wakeling.

If you're looking for more arcade sports games like Rematch, the fast-paced basketball video game NBA Bounce launches on consoles and PC on September 26. This cooperative 4v4 basketball game is designed for players of all ages, and lets you create custom players for your favorite NBA team or even play as each team's mascot. Physical edition preorders are available for $40 on Nintendo Switch, PS5, PS4, and Xbox Series X. While the in-game content seems to be the same across all versions, physical Switch copies include an exclusive bonus sticker sheet.

Similarly, Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds arrives on PS5, Xbox Series X|S, Switch, and PC a day earlier on September 25, and preordering at Amazon gets you a free poster. You can also reserve a copy of the recently announced Mario Tennis Fever ahead of its February 12, 2026 release on Switch 2. The new entry in the long-running Mario Tennis series introduces a bunch of new single-player content, mini-game challenges, and the biggest Mario Tennis roster yet, with 38 playable characters.

As mentioned above, EA Sports FC 26 is also launching soon on September 26. The newest entry in EA's annual soccer video game franchise is available to preorder on PS5, PS4, Xbox, Nintendo Switch 2, Switch, and PC, and grabbing an early copy gets you a bunch of in-game bonus items, XP boosts, and more. There's also a $100 digital-only Ultimate Edition that includes even more extras and lets you start playing a week early on September 19.

While EA Sports FC 26 is a good choice for anyone looking to play a more authentic adaptation of soccer--especially since it lets you play as real-world teams and players--if you're looking for a deep soccer club management simulator, the aptly titled Football Manager 26 is launching first on PC on November 4 and preorders are discounted to $49.19 (was $60) at Fanatical. The game will also launch on PS5, Nintendo Switch, Xbox, and Game Pass at a later date, though preorders for the console versions are not yet available.

item.title: Overwatch 2 Persona 5 Crossover Skins Are Ready To Steal Your Heart (And Wallet)
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The arrival of Persona 5's Phantom Thieves in Overwatch 2 on September 16 will mean more than just hearts are about to be stolen, as the game is set to introduce a number of new premium cosmetics based on Atlus' stylish JRPG that likely won't come cheap.

After having previously teased the collab, Blizzard has finally revealed the five main cosmetics players will be able to purchase as part of the Season 18 crossover. They are:

  • Wuyang as Joker
  • Mercy as Panther
  • Lifeweaver as Fox
  • D.Va as Queen
  • Genji as Skull

Whereas previous Overwatch collabs like Gundam Wing or Avatar: The Last Airbender have seen Blizzard put its own spin on how Overwatch's heroes might cosplay various characters, there isn't much creative license on display here. The Persona 5 skins for Overwatch 2 make the game's heroes look exactly as you expect them to, so much so that it is actually a little difficult to realize what hero is underneath the costume. There are, however, a few flourishes, such as rose petals falling from Mercy's wings and Wuyang's staff evoking Joker's Persona Arsene.

Wuyang is Overwatch 2's newest support hero and as such doesn't have many cosmetics to choose from just yet, so it's nice that he is featured prominently as part of the crossover. Mercy, on the other hand, is one of the game's most popular characters and is often featured in crossovers, so her donning the look of Panther is a bit of a no brainer. Blizzard hasn't released the exact prices for the skins just yet, but expect them to be similar to that of previous crossovers, which usually cost around 2,800 ($28) Overwatch Coins per skin bundle.

Outside of new skins, a few of Persona 5's visual flourishes will also make their way into Overwatch 2's menus, including a new piece of key art from Atlus character artist Shigenori Soejima. A Phantom Thieves-inspired overlay will also appear when viewing the Persona 5 cosmetics in the game's shop, a first for a collab, according to Blizzard.

For those who aren't keen on opening their wallets to the Phantom Thieves, Overwatch 2 collabs usually bring some freebies in the form of sprays, weapon charms, and player icons for those who complete various challenges. Overwatch 2's Persona 5 crossover will be live September 16-30.
